Title.En: Art-based Research Methods in Intercultural Competence and Multilingualism

NoteLiteral.En:
For whom?
This course is open for MA and PhD students. The students should be currently enrolled in an MA or PhD program, and have completed a BA (180 ECTS) in any of these: Humanities, Social Sciences, Teacher Education. 

Admission requirements
You must upload an official English copy of your bachelor transcript of records.
You must upload a document showing your enrolment in a MA or PhD program.
You must fill in all the information in the form linked under the section "application process". This information is required to complete the admission process at University of Stavanger.

Admission process
We process applications toward the end of the application period. If your application is accepted, you will receive an offer sent to your ECIU email address. Please remember to check your ECIU email and spam folder regularly, and note that you have 7 days to accept the offer.

Description.En: Intercultural skills have been recognized as the top-valued skills for not only employers in various industries but for education from the earliest age. Multilingualism goes hand in hand with intercultural competencies, and is already a stated goal for EU-education and a need in increasingly diverse working and living contexts. Therefore, the aim of the course is to explore and critically evaluate the key issues in research on intercultural competence and multilingualism, especially from the standpoint of teacher education and foreign language teaching.

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of the course, students will have expert knowledge of the scholarly theories within and specialized insights into intercultural competence (ICC) and multilingualism, e.g. approaches and methods in the study of multilingualism; central aspects of individual and/or societal multilingualism. They will be able to evaluate the feasibility and application of different methods and processes in research and scholarly projects related to ICC and multilingualism, e.g. evaluate differences in application and appropriateness of the techniques for different contexts. They can contribute to the development of new knowledge, methods, and interpretations related to the fields of ICC and multilingualism, e.g. design and analyse different art-based data elicitation techniques.

By the end of the course, the students can analyze and deal critically with various sources of information, and analyze existing theories, methods and interpretations in the field of ICC and multilingualism and work independently on practical and theoretical problems. They can formulate problems, plan and carry out research and scholarly development work, and handle complex academic issues and critically evaluate established knowledge and practice in the field of ICC and multilingualism.

PrefLabel.En: respect the diversity of cultural values and norms

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of the course, students can: analyze relevant academic, professional and research ethical problems; apply their knowledge and skills in new areas in order to carry out research with scholarly integrity; communicate extensive independent work and master language and terminology of the academic field; manage complex interdisciplinary assignments and projects; participate in debates in the field of ICC and multilingualism in international forums

- Krulatz, A., Dahl, A., & Flogenfeldt, M.E. (2018). Enacting Multilingualism. From Research to Teaching Practice in the English Classroom. Oslo: Cappelen Damm Akademisk. (selected chapters)

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
**For whom?**

The course is on a PhD level but both MA and PhD students can apply. The students should be currently enrolled in an MA or PhD program, and have completed a BA in any of these: Humanities, Social Sciences, Teacher Education. 

**Format**

The course is blended. The first meeting will be online, and will take place 3 weeks before the 5-day in-person course at UiS. The last session will be online, a week after the in-person course finishes. Attendance at both online sessions and physical course is mandatory.

**When?**

- First online session: 12.05.2025
- Last online session: 02.06.2025
- 5 day physical course in Stavanger: 19-23.05.2025

The physical course is done in a workshop format. The activities take place every day from 9am until 5pm. A 15-minute presentation is obligatory as well as 90% attendance. The final exam is a portfolio compiled and reflection note of 1000 words (+/-10%) based on in-class activities and discussions: to be submitted upon the end of the course. 

Final exam: 02.06.2025

**Funding to travel?**

Please contact your local/home university to check out the possibility to apply for funding for the travel and stay (mobility support). There might be an early deadline for this, so check this out as soon as you can.

**Housing and travel**

Due to the difficult housing situation in Stavanger, UiS cannot provide accommodation for shortterm international students. Therefore, you will have to find housing on the private market.

Please note that you are responsible for organizing your own travel.
